Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Shear Banding in Bulk Metallic Glasses
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY: Metallic glasses exhibit enormous yield strengths that exceed those of the strongest superalloys, but their use as structural materials is limited by their low ductility, the direct consequence of shear banding. The long-term research goal of this proposal is to characterize shear band propagation in bulk metallic glasses so that the extraordinary strengths of this unique class of materials can be exploited for use in structural applications. In pursuit of this goal, the research objectives are to test the hypotheses that 1) shear bands in bulk metallic glasses propagate simultaneously rather than progressively across a sample, 2) shear band velocities are typically on the order of millimeters per second during serrated flow, and 3) shear band velocity is a function of the imposed strain rate. The final failure event will be characterized, and the conditions under which a shear band propagates catastrophically will be determined. The research approach requires macro and microscale testing at strain rates spanning several orders of magnitude in concert with temporally and spatially resolved measurements of strain. Characterization techniques to be employed include high-speed video imaging and data acquisition from strain gages during uniaxial compression testing, microcompression testing using nanoindentation, scanning electron microscopy, and acoustic emission measurements of shear banding events.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY: ?Metallic glass? - the name suggests something quite remarkable. Metallic glasses and conventional metal alloys are typically combinations of several elements, such as aluminum, copper, nickel, and titanium. But whereas the atoms in conventional metals are arranged in orderly, crystalline arrays, the atomic arrangements in metallic glasses have no long-range order. The result is that the mechanical behavior of metallic glasses is fundamentally different from that of their crystalline counterparts. Most notably, metallic glasses are extraordinarily strong, but unfortunately, they exhibit macroscopically brittle behavior. Since bulk metallic glasses comprise a relatively new class of materials, the current understanding of their mechanical behavior is far less sophisticated than that of crystalline metals, particularly with respect to the atomic level and microscopic mechanisms of plastic deformation. The research goal of this proposal is to investigate the microscopic deformation mechanisms in metallic glasses through a combination of mechanical testing, materials characterization, and modeling so that the potential of metallic glasses as structural materials can be fully realized. A laboratory-based workshop on metallic glasses for first generation undergraduates majoring in engineering at Santa Clara University (SCU) will enhance the cultural capital of these students at an early point in their academic careers to maximize their opportunities for enrichment and success in college. This workshop will be adapted for use in other SCU outreach efforts for underserved high school students in the community. Results and insights gained from assessments of outreach to first generation college students and members of underrepresented groups will contribute to the development of best practices for promoting the participation of these students in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) fields. At a local level, these efforts will increase the number of students from first generation and underrepresented groups majoring in STEM fields.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Metallic glasses are non-crystalline materials, meaning that there is no pattern to the arrangement of the atoms in the alloys. As metallic glasses are not found in nature, they represent a rare class of truly synthetic materials. Since there is no pattern, there can be no defects (in the pattern) and consequently metallic glasses are extraordinarily strong. For the same reason, metallic glasses are brittle compared to conventional, crystalline metals, which is a direct consequence of the microscopic deformation mechanism known as shear banding. The key to improving the ductility of metallic glasses is to understand and control the shear bands. The goal of this project was to characterize shear band propagation in metallic glasses. Specifically, this project focused on high temporal resolution mechanical testing and synchronous high-speed imaging of metallic glasses.

Metallic glasses were compressed, and their deformation was imaged using a high-speed camera at rates as high as 80,000 frames per second (conventional video displays 30 frames per second). The images were synchronized with the applied load signal, which was acquired at 100,000 data points per second. Synchronous acoustic emission data were also acquired, and digital image correlation was used to generate displacement maps of the specimens during compression.

The outcomes of this CAREER Award contribute to a more thorough understanding of shear band propagation in metallic glasses. Key results are summarized below.

1. The temperature increases sustained during shear banding in metallic glasses are small, but the temperature increase during fracture is large.

2. Fracture fronts in metallic glasses propagate rapidly (less than 20 microseconds for millimeter-sized specimens). The drastically different time scales of fracture and shear banding imply that fracture is not the product of a runaway shear band but of a fundamentally different mechanism.

3. Two types of shear banding events occur during metallic glass deformation, typified by small and large serrations in the stress versus time profiles obtained during deformation. “Large” serrations show relatively large stress drops and a sharply peaked stress drop rate profile. All points in a shear band move simultaneously across the specimen during a large serration. “Small” serrations correspond to small stress drops, with fluctuating stress drop rates, indicating an intermittent propagation at the shear band front.

4. Shear bands propagate with speeds on the order of millimeters per second during quasistatic (slow) deformation. The stress drops of the large serration events are coincident in time with the shear band propagation.

5. The statistics and dynamics of the serrations show excellent agreement with the predictions of a simple mean field model that holds that metallic glasses deform via the propagation of slipping “weak spots,” thereby providing experimental evidence for the existence of shear transformation zones (i.e., weak spots) as the elementary mechanism of inhomogeneous deformation in metallic glasses.

6. The statistics of shear banding events in metallic glasses are similar to the slip statistics measured by others in small volumes of crystals, granular media, rocks, and even earthquakes. Together these findings suggest universality in the deformation of these systems.

Four undergraduate students and one post-doctoral researcher were trained as part of this project. Two female undergraduates subsequently pursued doctoral studies in engineering. Materials engineering workshops with an emphasis on metallic glasses were delivered to hundreds of middle school and high school students as part of Bucknell University’s Summer Engineering Camp. An independent study course on the processing, properties, and deformation of metallic glasses was offered.




Last Modified: 09/28/2016
Modified by: Wendelin Wright

As metallic glasses are not found in nature, they represent a rare class of truly synthetic materials. Since there is no pattern, there can be no defects (in the pattern) and consequently metallic glasses are extraordinarily strong. For the same reason, metallic glasses are brittle compared to conventional, crystalline metals, which is a direct consequence of the microscopic deformation mechanism known as shear banding. The key to improving the ductility of metallic glasses is to understand and control the shear bands. The goal of this project was to characterize shear band propagation in metallic glasses. Specifically, this project focused on high temporal resolution mechanical testing and synchronous high-speed imaging of metallic glasses. Metallic glasses were compressed, and their deformation was imaged using a high-speed camera at rates as high as 80,000 frames per second (conventional video displays 30 frames per second). The images were synchronized with the applied load signal, which was acquired at 100,000 data points per second. The temperature increases sustained during shear banding in metallic glasses are small, but the temperature increase during fracture is large. 2. The statistics of shear banding events in metallic glasses are similar to the slip statistics measured by others in small volumes of crystals, granular media, rocks, and even earthquakes.
